title: How to write 'die' in Japanese? What other words are based on that one - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you for the A2A. Cordelia already provided a fairly comprehensive list; I’ll complement with a few more words that may be common/handy. These were previously mentioned: 死ぬ：to die (shinu)死ね：Die! (shine) - as in an imperative死人：dead person (shinin)死者：one who is dead (shisha) - used in news articles, etc; not personal殉死：martyrdom (junshi)Some common words: 死：death (shi) - e.g. 死の恐怖（きょうふ）/ fear of death死因：cause of death (shiin)死骸：a corpse; a cadaver; a carcass (shigai) - usually for animals死亡：death (shibou) - e.g. 死亡する = to die死亡診断書：a death certificate (shibou shindansho)死亡広告：an obituary (shibou koukoku)Some interesting/related words: 死角：a blind spot (shikaku) - written “dead angle”犬死に：to die in vain (inujini) - written “die like a dog”e.g. 彼（かれ）は犬死にしたのではない / He didn’t die for nothing.自殺：suicide (jisatsu) - written “to kill oneself”他殺：death at someone else’s hand/murder (tasatsu)他界する：to pass away; die (takai suru) - written “other world”Advanced Cultural Tip: While such politeness is not expected of foreigners, this is for mega extra points if you know the difference. Traditionally, if you are talking about someone’s death personally, it’s considered bad luck / bad manners to use the word “死ぬ”. If you are talking politely about someone dying, you would use the verb亡くなる。(nakunaru - to die) This would be someone outside your own family. E.g. 昨日、佐藤さんが亡くなりました。Ms/Mr. Sato passed away yesterday. (Kinou Sato-san ga nakunari mashita.) On the other hand, if you are talking politely about your own family member dying, you would use a verb like旅立つ。(tabidatsu - to leave for/pass away) - written “travel to [the other side]” E.g. 昨日、母が旅立ちました。My mother passed away [left for…] yesterday. (Kinou haha ga tabidachi mashita.) Hope this helps!

死ぬ。to die (shi-nu) 死ね。 Die! (shi-ne) --- as in an imperative 死人。dead person (shi-nin) 死者。one who is dead (shisha) -- probably more common than the one above it. 殉死。ritual suicide following the death of one's lord (jun-shi) 豆腐の角に頭をぶつけて死ね。（とうふのかどにあたまをぶつけてしね  　　"hit your head on the corner of a piece of tofu and die!" -- this one is used in comic storytelling but the meaning is something like a "yo mama so dumb that..." kind of joke. I like it for some reason. I think my dad might have said it to me at one point when I did something really, really stupid.  lots more but this is probably enough?
